That subject of military bases almost invariably gets into all
discussions of the type X am describing. It is a timely subject in
this Mediterranean part of the world because the United States has recent¬
ly concluded agreements for air and naval bases in Greece and Spain.
It may be hard for Americans to understand how deeply some Italian
democrats resent the deal made with Franco Spain. First of all, Spain is
still on the conscience of western European democrats because Franco came
to power with the help of Mussolini and Hitler in the days when the
democracies were attempting to appease fascism. Secondly, the European,
who knows modem war first-hand, is very sensitive Indeed to the sugges¬
tion that bases in Spain are needed because it might be necessary to hold
the Russians at the Pyrenees barrier in any future conflict. Europeans —
Including Italians — feel that if they had to be liberated after first
being overrun by the Russian army there would not be much to liberate.
Iet*0 take one example of Italian reaction to the Spanish bases
transaction, from the Liberal weekly newspaper, II Mondo, which many
Italians will tell you is the best thing in Italian Journalism. All we
need for purposes of illustration is a sub-headline from II Mondo's
article after the American-Spanish agreement was concluded. This headline
saidt “The most ordinary strategic reasons and the most clever political
calculations cannot conceal one simple and Incontestable truths that the
Spain of Franco remains a totalitarian and fascist dictatorship.w
The Italian friend I cited above said the same thing with broader
application. He said:
“You Americans do a lot of talking about the defense of the free
world, but we'r© beginning to think those are Just nice words, we can't
take you very seriously when you Include as a part of that free world
Franco Spain — or, I might add, Tito's Yugoslavia.^
